Events.html: 495 BC – A newly constructed temple in honour of the god Mercury was dedicated in ancient Rome on the Circus Maximus, between the Aventine and Palatine hills. To spite the senate and the consuls, the people awarded the dedication to a senior military officer, Marcus Laetorius
Events.text: A newly constructed temple in honour of the god Mercury was dedicated in ancient Rome on the Circus Maximus, between the Aventine and Palatine hills. To spite the senate and the consuls, the people awarded the dedication to a senior military officer, Marcus Laetorius

Events.html: 392 – Emperor Valentinian II is assassinated while advancing into Gaul against the Frankish usurper Arbogast. He is found hanging in his residence at Vienne.
Events.text: Emperor Valentinian II is assassinated while advancing into Gaul against the Frankish usurper Arbogast. He is found hanging in his residence at Vienne.

Events.html: 589 – King Authari marries Theodelinda, daughter of the Bavarian duke Garibald I. A Catholic, she has great influence among the Lombard nobility.
Events.text: King Authari marries Theodelinda, daughter of the Bavarian duke Garibald I. A Catholic, she has great influence among the Lombard nobility.

Events.html: 1252 – Pope Innocent IV issues the papal bull ad extirpanda, which authorizes, but also limits, the torture of heretics in the Medieval Inquisition.
Events.text: Pope Innocent IV issues the papal bull ad extirpanda, which authorizes, but also limits, the torture of heretics in the Medieval Inquisition.

Events.html: 1525 – Insurgent peasants led by Anabaptist pastor Thomas Müntzer were defeated at the Battle of Frankenhausen, ending the German Peasants' War in the Holy Roman Empire.
Events.text: Insurgent peasants led by Anabaptist pastor Thomas Müntzer were defeated at the Battle of Frankenhausen, ending the German Peasants' War in the Holy Roman Empire.

Events.html: 1536 – Anne Boleyn, Queen of England, stands trial in London on charges of treason, adultery and incest. She is condemned to death by a specially-selected jury.
Events.text: Anne Boleyn, Queen of England, stands trial in London on charges of treason, adultery and incest. She is condemned to death by a specially-selected jury.

Events.html: 1567 – Mary, Queen of Scots marries James Hepburn, 4th Earl of Bothwell, her third husband.
Events.text: Mary, Queen of Scots marries James Hepburn, 4th Earl of Bothwell, her third husband.

Events.html: 1602 – Bartholomew Gosnold becomes the first recorded European to see Cape Cod.
Events.text: Bartholomew Gosnold becomes the first recorded European to see Cape Cod.

Events.html: 1618 – Johannes Kepler confirms his previously rejected discovery of the third law of planetary motion (he first discovered it on March 8 but soon rejected the idea after some initial calculations were made).
Events.text: Johannes Kepler confirms his previously rejected discovery of the third law of planetary motion (he first discovered it on March 8 but soon rejected the idea after some initial calculations were made).

Events.html: 1648 – The Treaty of Westphalia is signed.
Events.text: The Treaty of Westphalia is signed.

Events.html: 1701 – The War of the Spanish Succession begins.
Events.text: The War of the Spanish Succession begins.

Events.html: 1718 – James Puckle, a London lawyer, patents the world's first machine gun.
Events.text: James Puckle, a London lawyer, patents the world's first machine gun.

Events.html: 1755 – Laredo, Texas is established by the Spaniards.
Events.text: Laredo, Texas is established by the Spaniards.

Events.html: 1776 – American Revolution: the Virginia Convention instructs its Continental Congress delegation to propose a resolution of independence from Great Britain, paving the way for the United States Declaration of Independence.
Events.text: American Revolution: the Virginia Convention instructs its Continental Congress delegation to propose a resolution of independence from Great Britain, paving the way for the United States Declaration of Independence.

Events.html: 1791 – French Revolution: Maximilien Robespierre proposes the Self-denying Ordinance.
Events.text: French Revolution: Maximilien Robespierre proposes the Self-denying Ordinance.

Events.html: 1792 – War of the First Coalition: France declares war on Kingdom of Sardinia.
Events.text: War of the First Coalition: France declares war on Kingdom of Sardinia.

Events.html: 1793 – Diego Marín Aguilera flies a glider for "about 360 meters", at a height of 5–6 meters, during one of the first attempted manned flights.
Events.text: Diego Marín Aguilera flies a glider for "about 360 meters", at a height of 5–6 meters, during one of the first attempted manned flights.

Events.html: 1796 – First Coalition: Napoleon enters Milan in triumph.
Events.text: First Coalition: Napoleon enters Milan in triumph.

Events.html: 1800 – King George III of the United Kingdom survives an assassination attempt by James Hadfield, who is later acquitted by reason of insanity.
Events.text: King George III of the United Kingdom survives an assassination attempt by James Hadfield, who is later acquitted by reason of insanity.

links.subject: George III of the United Kingdom
links.title: George III of the United Kingdom

Events.html: 1811 – Paraguay declares independence from Spain.
Events.text: Paraguay declares independence from Spain.

Events.html: 1817 – Opening of the first private mental health hospital in the United States, the Asylum for the Relief of Persons Deprived of the Use of Their Reason (now Friends Hospital) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
Events.text: Opening of the first private mental health hospital in the United States, the Asylum for the Relief of Persons Deprived of the Use of Their Reason (now Friends Hospital) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

Events.html: 1836 – Francis Baily observes "Baily's beads" during an annular eclipse.
Events.text: Francis Baily observes "Baily's beads" during an annular eclipse.

Events.html: 1849 – Troops of the Two Sicilies take Palermo and crush the republican government of Sicily
Events.text: Troops of the Two Sicilies take Palermo and crush the republican government of Sicily

Events.html: 1850 – The Bloody Island Massacre takes place in Lake County, California, in which a large number of Pomo Indians in Lake County are slaughtered by a regiment of the United States Cavalry, led by Nathaniel Lyon.
Events.text: The Bloody Island Massacre takes place in Lake County, California, in which a large number of Pomo Indians in Lake County are slaughtered by a regiment of the United States Cavalry, led by Nathaniel Lyon.

Events.html: 1858 – Opening of the present Royal Opera House in Covent Garden, London.
Events.text: Opening of the present Royal Opera House in Covent Garden, London.

Events.html: 1862 – President Abraham Lincoln signs a bill into law creating the United States Bureau of Agriculture. It is later renamed the United States Department of Agriculture.
Events.text: President Abraham Lincoln signs a bill into law creating the United States Bureau of Agriculture. It is later renamed the United States Department of Agriculture.

Events.html: 1864 – American Civil War: Battle of Resaca, Georgia ends.
Events.text: American Civil War: Battle of Resaca, Georgia ends.

Events.html: 1864 – American Civil War: Battle of New Market, Virginia: Students from the Virginia Military Institute fight alongside the Confederate Army to force Union General Franz Sigel out of the Shenandoah Valley.
Events.text: American Civil War: Battle of New Market, Virginia: Students from the Virginia Military Institute fight alongside the Confederate Army to force Union General Franz Sigel out of the Shenandoah Valley.

Events.html: 1869 – Women's suffrage: in New York, Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton form the National Woman Suffrage Association.
Events.text: Women's suffrage: in New York, Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton form the National Woman Suffrage Association.

Events.html: 1891 – Pope Leo XIII defends workers' rights and property rights in the encyclical Rerum Novarum, the beginning of modern Catholic social teaching.
Events.text: Pope Leo XIII defends workers' rights and property rights in the encyclical Rerum Novarum, the beginning of modern Catholic social teaching.

Events.html: 1904 – Russo-Japanese War: The Russian minelayer Amur lays a minefield about 15 miles off Port Arthur and sinks Japan's battleships Hatsuse, 15,000 tons, with 496 crew and Yashima.
Events.text: Russo-Japanese War: The Russian minelayer Amur lays a minefield about 15 miles off Port Arthur and sinks Japan's battleships Hatsuse, 15,000 tons, with 496 crew and Yashima.

Events.html: 1905 – Las Vegas, is founded when 110 acres (0.45 km2), in what later would become downtown, are auctioned off.
Events.text: Las Vegas, is founded when 110 acres (0.45 km2), in what later would become downtown, are auctioned off.

Events.html: 1911 – In Standard Oil Company of New Jersey v. United States, the United States Supreme Court declares Standard Oil to be an "unreasonable" monopoly under the Sherman Antitrust Act and orders the company to be broken up.
Events.text: In Standard Oil Company of New Jersey v. United States, the United States Supreme Court declares Standard Oil to be an "unreasonable" monopoly under the Sherman Antitrust Act and orders the company to be broken up.

links.subject: Standard Oil Company of New Jersey v. United States
links.title: Standard Oil Company of New Jersey v. United States

links.subject: United States Supreme Court
links.title: Supreme Court of the United States

Events.html: 1919 – The Winnipeg General Strike begins. By 11:00, almost the whole working population of Winnipeg, Manitoba had walked off the job.
Events.text: The Winnipeg General Strike begins. By 11:00, almost the whole working population of Winnipeg, Manitoba had walked off the job.

Events.html: 1919 – Greek invasion of Smyrna. During the invasion, the Greek army kills or wounds 350 Turks. Those responsible are punished by the Greek Commander Aristides Stergiades.
Events.text: Greek invasion of Smyrna. During the invasion, the Greek army kills or wounds 350 Turks. Those responsible are punished by the Greek Commander Aristides Stergiades.

Events.html: 1928 – Walt Disney character Mickey Mouse premieres in his first cartoon, Plane Crazy
Events.text: Walt Disney character Mickey Mouse premieres in his first cartoon, Plane Crazy

Events.html: 1929 – A fire at the Cleveland Clinic in Cleveland, Ohio kills 123.
Events.text: A fire at the Cleveland Clinic in Cleveland, Ohio kills 123.

Events.html: 1932 – In an attempted coup d'état, the Prime Minister of Japan Inukai Tsuyoshi is murdered.
Events.text: In an attempted coup d'état, the Prime Minister of Japan Inukai Tsuyoshi is murdered.

Events.html: 1934 – Kārlis Ulmanis establishes an authoritarian government in Latvia.
Events.text: Kārlis Ulmanis establishes an authoritarian government in Latvia.

Events.html: 1935 – The Moscow Metro is opened to the public.
Events.text: The Moscow Metro is opened to the public.

Events.html: 1940 – USS Sailfish is recommissioned. It was originally the USS Squalus.
Events.text: USS Sailfish is recommissioned. It was originally the USS Squalus.

Events.html: 1940 – World War II: After fierce fighting, the poorly trained and equipped Dutch troops surrender to Germany, marking the beginning of five years of occupation.
Events.text: World War II: After fierce fighting, the poorly trained and equipped Dutch troops surrender to Germany, marking the beginning of five years of occupation.

Events.html: 1940 – McDonald's opens its first restaurant in San Bernardino, California.
Events.text: McDonald's opens its first restaurant in San Bernardino, California.

Events.html: 1941 – First flight of the Gloster E.28/39 the first British and Allied jet aircraft.
Events.text: First flight of the Gloster E.28/39 the first British and Allied jet aircraft.

Events.html: 1942 – World War II: in the United States, a bill creating the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps (WAAC) is signed into law.
Events.text: World War II: in the United States, a bill creating the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps (WAAC) is signed into law.

Events.html: 1943 – Joseph Stalin dissolves the Comintern (or Third International).
Events.text: Joseph Stalin dissolves the Comintern (or Third International).

Events.html: 1945 – World War II: The Battle of Poljana, the final skirmish in Europe is fought near Prevalje, Slovenia.
Events.text: World War II: The Battle of Poljana, the final skirmish in Europe is fought near Prevalje, Slovenia.

Events.html: 1948 – Following the demise of Mandatory Palestine, the Kingdom of Egypt, Transjordan, Lebanon, Syria, Iraq and Saudi Arabia invade Israel thus starting the 1948 Arab–Israeli War.
Events.text: Following the demise of Mandatory Palestine, the Kingdom of Egypt, Transjordan, Lebanon, Syria, Iraq and Saudi Arabia invade Israel thus starting the 1948 Arab–Israeli War.

Events.html: 1951 – The Polish cultural attaché in Paris, Czesław Miłosz, asks the French government for political asylum.
Events.text: The Polish cultural attaché in Paris, Czesław Miłosz, asks the French government for political asylum.

Events.html: 1953 – Cubmaster Don Murphy organized the first pinewood derby, in Manhattan Beach, California, by Pack 280c.
Events.text: Cubmaster Don Murphy organized the first pinewood derby, in Manhattan Beach, California, by Pack 280c.

Events.html: 1957 – At Malden Island in the Pacific Ocean, Britain tests its first hydrogen bomb in Operation Grapple.
Events.text: At Malden Island in the Pacific Ocean, Britain tests its first hydrogen bomb in Operation Grapple.

Events.html: 1958 – The Soviet Union launches Sputnik 3.
Events.text: The Soviet Union launches Sputnik 3.

Events.html: 1960 – The Soviet Union launches Sputnik 4.
Events.text: The Soviet Union launches Sputnik 4.

Events.html: 1963 – Project Mercury: The launch of the final Mercury mission, Mercury-Atlas 9 with astronaut L. Gordon Cooper on board. He becomes the first American to spend more than a day in space.
Events.text: Project Mercury: The launch of the final Mercury mission, Mercury-Atlas 9 with astronaut L. Gordon Cooper on board. He becomes the first American to spend more than a day in space.

Events.html: 1966 – After a policy dispute, Prime Minister Nguyễn Cao Kỳ of South Vietnam's ruling junta launches a military attack on the forces of General Tôn Thất Đính, forcing him to abandon his command.
Events.text: After a policy dispute, Prime Minister Nguyễn Cao Kỳ of South Vietnam's ruling junta launches a military attack on the forces of General Tôn Thất Đính, forcing him to abandon his command.

Events.html: 1969 – People's Park: California Governor Ronald Reagan has an impromptu student park owned by University of California at Berkeley fenced off from student anti-war protestors, sparking a riot called Bloody Thursday.
Events.text: People's Park: California Governor Ronald Reagan has an impromptu student park owned by University of California at Berkeley fenced off from student anti-war protestors, sparking a riot called Bloody Thursday.

Events.html: 1970 – President Richard Nixon appoints Anna Mae Hays and Elizabeth P. Hoisington the first female United States Army Generals.
Events.text: President Richard Nixon appoints Anna Mae Hays and Elizabeth P. Hoisington the first female United States Army Generals.

Events.html: 1970 – Philip Lafayette Gibbs and James Earl Green are killed at Jackson State University by police during student protests.
Events.text: Philip Lafayette Gibbs and James Earl Green are killed at Jackson State University by police during student protests.

Events.html: 1972 – Okinawa, under U.S. military governance since its conquest in 1945, reverts to Japanese control.
Events.text: Okinawa, under U.S. military governance since its conquest in 1945, reverts to Japanese control.

Events.html: 1972 – In Laurel, Maryland, Arthur Bremer shoots and paralyzes Alabama Governor George Wallace while he is campaigning to become President.
Events.text: In Laurel, Maryland, Arthur Bremer shoots and paralyzes Alabama Governor George Wallace while he is campaigning to become President.

Events.html: 1974 – Ma'alot massacre: Members of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine attack and take hostages at an Israeli school; a total of 31 people are killed, including 22 schoolchildren.
Events.text: Ma'alot massacre: Members of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine attack and take hostages at an Israeli school; a total of 31 people are killed, including 22 schoolchildren.

links.subject: Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine
links.title: Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine

Events.html: 1986 – Elio de Angelis, was killed while testing the Brabham BT55 at the Paul Ricard circuit at Le Castellet.
Events.text: Elio de Angelis, was killed while testing the Brabham BT55 at the Paul Ricard circuit at Le Castellet.

Events.html: 1987 – The Soviet Union launches the Polyus prototype orbital weapons platform. It fails to reach orbit.
Events.text: The Soviet Union launches the Polyus prototype orbital weapons platform. It fails to reach orbit.

Events.html: 1988 – Soviet war in Afghanistan: After more than eight years of fighting, the Soviet Army begins its withdrawal from Afghanistan.
Events.text: Soviet war in Afghanistan: After more than eight years of fighting, the Soviet Army begins its withdrawal from Afghanistan.

Events.html: 1991 – Édith Cresson becomes France's first female premier.
Events.text: Édith Cresson becomes France's first female premier.

Events.html: 1997 – The United States government acknowledges the existence of the "Secret War" in Laos and dedicates the Laos Memorial in honor of Hmong and other "Secret War" veterans.
Events.text: The United States government acknowledges the existence of the "Secret War" in Laos and dedicates the Laos Memorial in honor of Hmong and other "Secret War" veterans.

Events.html: 2006 – Cloud Gate was formally dedicated in Chicago's Millennium Park.
Events.text: Cloud Gate was formally dedicated in Chicago's Millennium Park.

Events.html: 2008 – California becomes the second U.S. state after Massachusetts in 2004 to legalize same-sex marriage after the state's own Supreme Court rules a previous ban unconstitutional.
Events.text: California becomes the second U.S. state after Massachusetts in 2004 to legalize same-sex marriage after the state's own Supreme Court rules a previous ban unconstitutional.

Events.html: 2010 – Jessica Watson becomes the youngest person to sail, non-stop and unassisted around the world solo.
Events.text: Jessica Watson becomes the youngest person to sail, non-stop and unassisted around the world solo.

Events.html: 2013 – An upsurge in violence in Iraq leaves more than 389 people dead over three days.
Events.text: An upsurge in violence in Iraq leaves more than 389 people dead over three days.
